issue.title: Silently skip `module-info.java`

repository.name: google-java-format
repository.description: Reformats Java source code to comply with Google Java Style.

issue.body: Silently skip `module-info.java` until it's syntax is supported. Solution 1 from #75

body: I'd prefer (2), but I'm also not sure what the timeline is for ecj's java 9 support.
I prefer (2) as well, but (1) could serve as an interim solution, until ECJ supports Java 9.
Latest module syntax with layout example can be found here: http://cr.openjdk.java.net/~mr/jigsaw/spec/lang-vm.html
Any news on ecj's java 9 support? The `com.google.errorprone:javac:9-dev-r3297-1-shaded` does not contain it, I guess.
We migrated from ecj to javac. javac has JDK 9 support, but I'm not sure if the version the formatter is using is new enough.

According to http://central.maven.org/maven2/com/google/errorprone/javac/ there's a:
- [9-dev-r4023-2](http://central.maven.org/maven2/com/google/errorprone/javac/9-dev-r4023-2/)

But it is missing the `-shaded` suffix: [9-dev-r3297-1-shaded](http://central.maven.org/maven2/com/google/errorprone/javac/9-dev-r3297-1-shaded/)

Although the file size suggests it _does_ include all dependencies... but `org.openjdk.tools.javac.**.*` types are missing.

Seems like the update of `javac` would solve this problem, if `-source 9` could be specified:

```
com.google.googlejavaformat.java.FormatterException: 1:2: error: modules are not supported in -source 1.8
  (use -source 9 or higher to enable modules)

	at com.google.googlejavaformat.java.Formatter.getFormatReplacements(Formatter.java:242)
	at com.google.googlejavaformat.java.Formatter.formatSource(Formatter.java:216)
	at com.google.googlejavaformat.java.Formatter.formatSource(Formatter.java:202)
	at com.google.googlejavaformat.java.Java9SourceTest.issue75(Java9SourceTest.java:30)
```

issue.title: Add (ignored) test cases for Java 9 syntax related issues

repository.name: google-java-format
repository.description: Reformats Java source code to comply with Google Java Style.

issue.body:
This PR adds file `Java9SourceTest.java` to show the problems with Java 9 syntax features and the new `javac` version included in https://github.com/sormuras/google-java-format/commit/fee1ed2685f0b4b60cafde2b5204b11ad5bc69c5

- #75 
- #155 
- #176 

This PR also fixes a typo in `TryWithResources.input` and `TryWithResources.output`.

body:
I added initial support for this in c31bb191022d549eb612d02129f6fbb70e9d55fe. If anyone's interested in trying it out, please report any issues you find - we don't have a huge corpus of `module-info`s to test against yet.

I'll cut a new release soon that includes that change unless any issues turn up.

> I'll cut a new release soon that includes that change unless any issues turn up.

Great news! _(With tiny chance seeing #106 included as well?)_

While running against all 350 module descriptors found in an [OpenJDK](https://github.com/AdoptOpenJDK/openjdk-jdk9) mirror, I found something in `openjdk-jdk9\langtools\test\jdk\javadoc\doclet\testModules\moduletags\module-info.java`:

```
@Deprecated
module moduletags {
    requires transitive static moduleA;

    exports testpkgmdltags;
}
```

Looks a like file to test the "(one of)" rule from the `requires` production.

Here is the error message, with some more invalid(?) module files:
```
>>>> 1792: did not generate token "static"
openjdk-jdk9\langtools\test\jdk\javadoc\doclet\testModules\moduletags\module-info.java:42:33: error: did not generate token "static"

openjdk-jdk9\langtools\test\tools\javac\diags\examples\InvalidModuleDirective\module-info.java:28:4: error: module directive keyword or '}' expected

openjdk-jdk9\langtools\test\tools\javac\diags\examples\UnexpectedTokenInModuleInfo\module-info.java:26:2: error: class, interface, or enum expected

openjdk-jdk9\langtools\test\tools\javac\modules\InvalidModuleDirective\module-info.java:10:4: error: module directive keyword or '}' expected
```

All other **346** `module-info.java` files were successfully formatted.
Thanks for testing! f74657cbbe11c51f8b2b4810daa7c84ca6c6a552 fixes the issue with `requires transitive static`.

issue.title: Support Java > 11 language features

repository.name: google-java-format
repository.description: Reformats Java source code to comply with Google Java Style.

issue.body:
Afaict, GJF runs flawlessly on Java source code units up to [Java Language Specification](https://docs.oracle.com/javase/specs/) 11. That includes formatting `module-info.java` files.

- [x] _JDK 9 `module-info.java` handling_ **(Standard)**  #75 

With new official Java syntax being potentially introduced every six months, GJF fails on those files that already make use of new language features. Such as Switch Expressions, Text Blocks, or Records. Here's an excerpt of the [JDK 14 feature list](https://openjdk.java.net/projects/jdk/14/) which are relevant for GJF's goal "reformatting Java source code": 

- [x] Pattern Matching for instanceof (Preview) [JEP 305](https://openjdk.java.net/jeps/305)  - 
- [x] Records (Preview) [JEP 359](https://openjdk.java.net/jeps/359)  - 
- [x] Switch Expressions **(Standard)** [JEP 361](https://openjdk.java.net/jeps/361)  #340
- [x] Text Blocks (Second Preview, Standard with Java 15) [JEP 368](https://openjdk.java.net/jeps/368)  #382 

GJF should either support those features and format them or by-pass any "unknown blocks" automagically and format the rest of the source unit as good as possible.

Follow-up from: #387 _Support foundation `javac`_
Related thread on twitter: https://twitter.com/sormuras/status/1221515240854229000
